newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks surge yet again to 6-year high close.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks surge yet again to 6-year high close.

text.p: Taiwan share prices surged through resistance at 8,400 points on Monday to yet another six-year high, though some brokers warned of growing technical vulnerability in the liquidity-driven rally.
The weighted index advanced 135.11 points or 1.63 percent to close at its intra-day high of 8,426.42.
Monday's close surpassed the 8,291.31 finish on March 15 to marked the index's highest close since it reached 8,569.55 on May 15, 1990. Turnover was a sizzling T$176.88 billion.
Blue chip electronics jumped 2.99 percent while the plastics sector gained 2.29 percent gain.

"Today's sharp gains show investors are confident that the market's bull run will continue. It means very little to tell them where the peak is," said Joe Chiou, a Taiwan Securities Investment analyst who feels the index has more room to rise.
Some brokers had expected the index to consolidate at 8,400, questioning whether the long rise reflected fundamental value.
"This is nothing but a liquidity-driven rally. Money is abundant and people are always looking for their next target," Chen Han-chung of Yungli Securities said.
Ben Lee of Nomura Securities was cautious. "Technically it is time for a correction," Lee said.
The index has risen an impressive 23.5 percent in 1997, making it one of the best performing markets in the world.

Monday's close also represented a 70.5 percent rise compared with a year ago, when rival China was mounting war games and missile tests near Taiwan during the island's March 1996 direct presidential election in a bid to intimidate Taiwan voters not to drop an official pledge to reunify with the mainland.
High-technology shares remained the market's stars, with semiconductor maker United Microelectronics up by the daily seven percent limit to T$54.
